title: 106_s730
content: SHORT TITLE, FINDINGS. The "Fire Safe Cigarette Act of 1999" aims to establish a cigarette fire safety standard due to the high number of deaths, injuries, and property damage caused by cigarette ignited fires in the United States. Congress has found that over 1,000 deaths and $420 million in property damage were caused by such fires in 1996 alone. Additionally, more than 100 children die each year from cigarette-related fires. The technical groundwork for this standard has already been laid out by previous acts. The Consumer Product Safety Commission found that the absence of a cigarette fire safety standard costs $6 billion annually, supporting the need for regulatory expertise to implement such a standard. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The term "cigarette" is defined as per the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act. "Stockpiling" is the manufacturing or importing of cigarettes at a rate higher than the previous year before a new rule is implemented. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must establish a cigarette fire safety standard within 18 months to reduce ignition risks. They will consult with the National Institute of Standards and Technology and consider input from other federal and state agencies. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must establish a cigarette fire safety standard within 18 months, considering input from various agencies. The rule will prohibit stockpiling of cigarettes covered and take effect within 30 months of enactment. The rule under subsection (a) shall be promulgated in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code. No other provision of Federal law shall apply with respect to the promulgation of this rule, including the Consumer Product Safety Act, chapter 6 of title 5, the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, and the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996. Judicial Review: Any person affected by the rule may file a petition with the Court of Appeals within 60 days for review. The Commission must provide the court with the record of the proceedings. The Court of Appeals may order additional evidence to be taken before the Commission in a hearing, upon petition and demonstration of need. The Court of Appeals may order additional evidence to be taken before the Commission in a hearing, upon petition and demonstration of need. Such evidence must be material and not previously available during the Commission's proceeding. The Commission can modify its findings based on this new evidence and must submit the modified findings to the court. The Commission may make recommendations for modifying a rule, subject to court review under chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code. The Small Business Act does not apply to a cigarette fire safety standard or enforcement actions related to it. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Prohibition on manufacturing or importing non-compliant cigarettes and failure to provide required information. Violations subject to penalty under the Consumer Product Safety Act. SEC. 5. PREEMPTION. SEC. 5. PREEMPTION. This Act does not override state laws with stricter cigarette fire safety standards. Compliance with the federal standard cannot be used as a defense in civil actions for damages.
